name: breath
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
B1 [ U ] the air that goes into and out of your lungs: out of breath He burst into the room, red-faced and out of breath (= unable to breathe comfortably because of tiredness or excitement).short of breath She was dizzy and short of breath (= unable to breathe in enough air). Her breath smelled of garlic. catch your breath ( also get your breath, get your breath back)
C1 to pause or rest for a short time until you can breathe comfortably or regularly again: I had to stop running to catch my breath.
See more draw breath (also draw a breath)
to breathe: Without pausing to draw breath she told me everything.
to pause for a short time between doing one thing and the next: Give me a minute to draw breath, won't you?
See more hold your breath
B2 to keep air in your lungs and not release it so that you need more: How long can you hold your breath under water?
C2 to wait for something to happen, often feeling anxious: Fans held their breath waiting for the final whistle.
See more
[ C ] a single action of breathing air into your lungs take a breath
B2 to breathe air into your lungs (as a single action): take a deep breath The doctor told me to take a deep breath (= breathe in a lot of air).
See more a breath of air
the smallest amount of wind: There wasn't a breath of air in the room.
a short period of time spent outside: I'm just going out for a breath of (fresh) air - I won't be long.
See more
More examplesFewer examplesHer breath reeked of garlic.I heard his breath rasping in his chest.The disease may cause cold sweating, nausea, vomiting and shortness of breath .She paused to get her breath back and then carried on jogging.It's terribly smoky in here - I'm just going out for a breath of fresh air.
